intro: Chupalon pseudopubescens, commonly known as the hairy chupalon, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants like buckwheat and sorrel. The plant is characterized by its upright, herbaceous stems and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine, hairy glands, giving it a distinctive texture. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in mountainous habitats.
